p: A major argument against universal public masking in addition to other public health measures has been limited supplies of personal protective equipment, including surgical masks, in the face of a sudden pandemic for which HCWs must be prioritized. We cannot conflate what we think should be done and what can be done. Industries in the United States can repurpose to produce surgical masks in vast quantities for the public [ 48] (as in Taiwan) [ 45], and such production will allow equal access to mask supplies across all strata of society. The CDC has provided guidance on which cloth materials are the most effective for preventing the spread of respiratory droplets [ 12, 49], although ensuring that equality to access is imperative and recommendations on how to prolong the life of disposable masks and reuse masks are widespread [ 50]. Another major concern is that the public will let their “guard down” with masking [ 2]. This can be addressed with strong public health messaging performed in tandem with new policy.
